Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A bride-to-be and her entourage arrive early, visibly anxious about the tight wedding schedule.
Story:
I was in the middle of prepping my station when my phone buzzed—my younger sister, Mia, again. We’d argued last night, and she wanted to talk things out, to clear the air. I knew I should call her back, listen, and try to rebuild the trust between us. But just then, the salon door swung open. The bride-to-be and her bridesmaids rushed in, all nerves and excitement, chattering about the schedule. As their hairdresser, I was expected to greet them warmly, put them at ease, and keep everything running smoothly. My manager shot me a look, reminding me how important it was to make clients feel special, especially on a day like this.

My phone vibrated again in my pocket. I felt torn—my sister needed me to be present, to show her she mattered, but my clients needed my full attention, too. I could feel the pressure mounting, my heart racing as I tried to decide who needed me more in that moment.
